issue.body:
This is a proposal of auto-accepting shared folders from a trusted devices.

For example, if i want to add more and more shares on my servers, i must on every server to accept the shares, every share, on every device.

If the share come from the trusted (added) device, maybe to have an option on device, to check a box, if the device is trusted (or own), and to give an standard folder location on the server or machine, where the auto-accepted shares would go (maybe, if the auto-accepted share is on, then, on this standard folder, the syncthing maybe create an subfolder with the name of shared folder, to have it sorted, if there are many shared folders), and would be accepted automaticaly.

Like this, user must not manualy accept every share, on every sync machines (devices), separatelly. Just add the shares on local machine, or local server, and have it done on all other machines (devices, or servers).

Devs, what you think? Is this an good idea?

issue.body:
I'm missing some things from the first day I installed Syncthing. Really small improvements but important in my opinion.

  The order of fields and features of fields when entering a new shared folder, right now are like that:

1-FOLDER LABEL (you have to enter it manually and/or copypaste it from 3rd field)
2-FOLDER ID (could keep being automatic, you don't have to worry about it I think)
3-FOLDER PATH (you have to enter manually the full path. I know popup some options while you are typing the correct path, but...)

I think it will be much easier to enter a new folder as:

1-FOLDER PATH [BROWSE...]. In which you can enter a path manually or use the browse button and select it. Of course, when you enter browse you should fall into the 'Default path' feature commented at  issue #2157. For sure almost all of us have a SYNCTHINGshares (or whatever) folder in which we first create our new folder and copy things in, and then we jump to the web browser to share it. Falling directly into our SYNCTHINGshares, will be great.

2-FOLDER LABEL. It should be taken automatically right after you have selected the folder path, just by adding the folder name as the 'folder label' here. For example with the sample above SYNCTHINGshares\MyMusic, 'MyMusic' should be the auto-proposal of syncthing when filling the 'folder label' field. 99% times user will left folder label with that name.

3-FOLDER ID. This could be even greyed out and not editable, almost transparent for the final user, first time I enter a folder I didn't know if I should change the given name or not or what.

body: it would also be great to have an option that if enabled restricts the selection of folders to that default parent path. (and may even hide the parent path from users.)
No, that makes no sense at all.

> No, that makes no sense at all.

that is hardly an argument in that form.

my phrasing may be misleading, but i don't have a clue what the misunderstanding could be if you provide such unfounded judgement.

my motivation in short is: users shouldn't be able to browse the filesystem as a whole.

Under what circunstances does a user who installed a piece of software would want to limit himself from being able to access/share certain parts of the filesystem? Why would you ever want that as a user?

I guess this could be useful if the server admin/owner is different from
the syncthing user/users.

I mean it's possible to setup chrooted users with separate Syncthing
configs and ports for the web UI. So if someone wants to offer some kind
of "Syncthing hosting" or allow some friends to use their servers
resources, limiting the filesystem access to a certain root path would
probably be the only feature missing from Syncthing to compartmentalize
the different use cases.

However the only problem I can see with the current behaviour is that
one can explore the files and folder structure via the autocomplete
function in the path field. Which can be remediated by simply chrooting
the user of this specific synctin instance to it's home.

And if one actually wants to protect their own server from certain users
and the public then it's already important to limit the attack surface
by using a special Syncthing user and only allowing access to the web UI
via SSH port forwarding.

Thus this is IMHO not a feature Syncthing should provide, because
compartmentalization is best handled by the underlying OS/rights management.

> it's possible to setup chrooted users with separate Syncthing configs and ports for the web UI

... and this is indeed the correct solution to the problem of the installer not being the same person as the user and wanting to limit access to the system at large.

(Syncthing is very easy to chroot. The only thing it needs access to is the DNS resolver config and CA certificates plus one or two required system libraries.)

**Discussing this further should be in a separate issue created for the purpose.** It'll just get lost in the noise here.

> Under what circunstances does a user who installed a piece of software would want to limit himself from being able to access/share certain parts of the filesystem?
- i'm providing syncfile-instances for users as Docker containers
- with volumes mounted at a certain path that i can guarantee will persist
- the users should be prevented from doing something against their own interest (choosing a path outside that volume)
- the users don't need to be confronted with parts of the filesystem she/he may find rather confusing, but rather enjoy a simple interface

this is not a proposal concerning technicalities, but about that thing they call User Experience. like the initial proposal as i understand it.
This is unrelated to this issue. Please create one for the purpose.
Somehow Github didn't pick up on #4192 and finally https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/commit/a04b92332f3ce8560bb339c1afb00037adbdd14e which should have closed this.
